title: The contradiction in the game is kinda annoying...

replies.body: Wowo ur so observant but that is actually true yea riot pls

Even if stars are created by him, they can still be considered birthed.
When he says "there are no dragons like me" the emphasis is on the "me". Such could even be a line by Draven.

English Language isn't that hard, yet it's the things contradicting itself.

Also Wolf is a spiritual wolf not just a head.

That would be true, if he didn't specifically say they are 'NOT' born.

Wolf is indeed a spriritual Wolf, but he IS just a head, unlike popular belief, Kindred is NOT one of the champs like Tahm kench and bard who's current form is only the depiction from stories and tales, and who's proper form is unknown. 
Kindred does physically look like that and always has (since they split in two) 
Also if their firm changed then it would break the key factor about kindred which is that you have to choose between Lambs 'arrow' or Wolf's 'teeth' if their form was ever changing then she might not have an arrow suddenly, and wolf may not have a mouth.

Also while we have grown up with it an know it, English is actually considered one of the hardest languages in the world to learn, so saying it isn't that hard is kind of a floating statement.

When he says that the stars are not born, he means they don't simply come into existence, he then goes on to say how they are.

I highly doubt Wolf is always just a head, especially considering the only feature Lamb has that is sheepish is her feet and fleece, all over she looks human, for all I know she could be a human wearing a lamb onesie.

Yes the English language is hard to learn, but you grew up with it nonetheless, therefore you should know innately how to decipher it's contradictions and simple play on language formation like is shown here.
Not every champion is going to be like Diana and be completely straight forward and literal like "A man, a woman and a yordle walk into the sun. THEY DIE! Because it burns them alive?".

I would have been disappointed if Aurelion Sol didn't speak in an almost Shakespearean manner.

I know what he means, but the wording is contradictory thats my whole point.

Wether you doubt it or not thats the way it is. Wolf is a wolf's head and lamb is a humanoid lamb, neither are human but neither are fully animalistic either, I'm not sure what your point about lamb is, she is humanoid because people relate better to humanoid characters than non humanoid ones, but there is clearly enough 'lamb' features for someone who knows nothing about her to realise that she is either a lamb/sheep or a goat. if you just had a little lamb running around on all 4 legs Baaaaaaaaa-ing at people it wouldn't quite be the same.
no non humanoid champion has a popularity of over 10% (they don't even make it close to that even) because people relate better to people characters, even kha'zix is humanoid. The only Dog feature that nasus has is his face, but thats enough for you to make the animal connection.

I did grow up with it and i understand how it works, and thats why i made this post in the first place, because their wording is contradictory (I'm talking about wording here remember, not meaning) 

and thank god that all champs are not like diana, that would be boring as fuck, but theres a line between interesting and contradictory.
Look at Jhin for example, his lines are badass but most of them mean absolutely nothing at all, not saying thats a bad thing but they are cool without being contradictory.

I agree that the way Aurelion sol speaks is awesome, Neil Kaplan was the perfect choice, any other actor wouldn't have brought it to life as well.

The wording is meant to be contradictory and distracting. Kind of like in Macbeth.
Can not be killed by a man born of woman.

Obviously you have to be born of woman, but being extracted via cesarean counts as not being born of woman.
Apply the same logic to Aurelion's quotes and it makes sense.

End of the day Aurelion Sol is a space dragon with a god complex.

I like the discussion, don't get me wrong, but I don't really have much to add.

I just wanted to jump in and say that it was specified (I can't remember if it was in quotes or lore) that Kindred is perceived differently by everyone. They are death itself, and everyone views death differently (also hence the quote "I wonder how they see me" and Wolf replies "Ashes on wool" as how he sees Lamb). So yes actually, Kindred is one of those champs of whom we see only one possible depiction :)

hmmm maybe, I was under the impression that it was just their names that were seen differently though, but if that is the case then how can everyone choose between lambs arrow and wolf's teeth, if their form doesn't always have a bow and arrow and wolfilke teeth?

also if wolf sees lamb as how she is in the game then surely that is their true form (especially because they call eachother lamb and wolf, meaning there true form must be that of a lamb and wolf.) also Magga sees kindred how they are in the game as well (shown in their teaser story) which means wolf and Magga see lamb in the same way (which immediately questions the theory that everyone sees kindred differently) that is further proven by how even before Magga sees kindred, the actors on the stage play dress as a lamb and a wolf with identical masks to kindred's actual ones, which means more people before Magga have seen kindred as a lamb and a wolf, so this means that The lamb and wolf is their true form, and its most likely that 'people perceiving death differently' is a metaphor about perceiving it as a peaceful end (lambs arrow) or something to be feared (wolfs teeth) and not actually that kindred's image changes for each person.

Well my understanding is that Kindred as a whole is basically a metaphor for death. Kindred as an actual entity is very ambiguous. 

> if their form doesn't always have a bow and arrow and wolfilke teeth?

I feel the references are very metaphorical here. Lamb's bow is a metaphor for a peaceful death, and Wolf's teeth for a not so peaceful one. You could supply whatever appropriate metaphor you wished.

> also Magga sees kindred how they are in the game as well

The particular legend seen in the teaser depicts them as a Lamb and a Wolf, Magga likely sees them this way because this is what she expects death to be from the legends that she knows, just as someone who knows death as the grim reaper might expect to see something more like Thresh or Karthus waiting for them. Just because everyone CAN see death differently, doesn't mean they will, and our perceptions are coloured by the things we learn, there is no such thing as an unbiased perspective (you can be objective, but you perception will still always be different because of your experiences).

> which means wolf and Magga see lamb in the same way

Ashes on wool is pretty loose. It implies a lamb/sheep certainly, but isn't definite. It could be that he sees her not as a Lamb, but rather as the actual ashes and 'on wool' is simply poetic, the aftermath of destruction that enables new life. It was hinted that Kindred has no 'true form' but given the ambiguity you could probably consider Lamb and Wolf Kindred's true form if you wanted. 

But we also don't know how much the dying person sees of them. When Kindred speak, does the person hear them, or do they talk only to themselves unless they wish otherwise? Perhaps someone who survived an encounter with Kindred like Magga did heard Wolf say that, and the legend formed around their story, creating the legend of Lamb and Wolf as we know it.

> "Stars are not born, they are made, by me."
"I grieve for every star never born."

Stars are born & made by Aurelion Sol ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡° )

EDIT:

> "There are no dragons like me."
"Celestial dragons live and die by our own rules."
So.. are there more celestial dragons? or is he the only one? again... pick one..

 probably means that 

1) There are no more celestial dragons
2) There are no celestial dragons other than Aurelion Sol on Summoner's Rift.

Definition of our:
>2. used in formal contexts by a royal person or a writer or editor to refer to something belonging to or associated with himself or herself.

Because they are his rules (and he sees himself as a god) then the use of our in that context is fine.

For the first one, born and made can be used basically as synonyms but yeah it sounds a bit sussed, as the first one seems to be used to talk down while the other should be using his own words.

As for Kindred, remember that the version we are seeing of wolf is as they are in the League (for lack of a better way to describe it, like really Rito?) more or less if wolf is released to kill someone it is very possible that he then has claws, the claws part could also be referring to lambs hands (as we all know wolf has some trouble with words, he may be using lambs hands as his claws without knowledge otherwise.) or it could even be used to refer to their job, in that they can't run.

These can all be interpreted as wrong, but because we don't know the actual interpretation (the one Rito holds) it's hard to know if these are mistakes or purposeful.
